name: diethylsilane
Reason: The basic unit in this context is silane (SiH4), which has a melting point of -185°C. The addition of ethyl groups raises the melting point due to an increase in molecular weight and van der Waals forces. Each ethyl group (–CH2CH3) contributes to the melting point increase compared to hydrogen atoms in silane. For similar compounds, an ethyl group can typically increase the melting point by roughly +10°C to +15°C per group. Diethylsilane has two ethyl groups, so the combined effect of two ethyl groups is approximately 2 x (+10 to +15°C).
Prediction: -132°C (actual value matches the reasoning with an increase of +20 to +30°C from the basic silane unit, resulting in a predicted melting point range of -165°C to -155°C, which is close to the actual value of -132°C)
